alfredsnippet.snippet:
George Adams, Lectures on Natural and Experimental Philosophy âˆ‘, IV 1799: 304

"Philosophy owes much to the assistance it has received from mathematicians; but this only happens when they apply themselves to the study of phenomena; when neglecting those, calculations are made to serve an hypothesis; the more elegant and beautiful they are, the more detrimental they become to science."
alfredsnippet.name: Phys.org Post - The Trouble with Mathematicians Who Don't Study Phenomena
